English (United States)(en-US): <nickname>, what's this?
This black smudge on\nthe piece of bread.
Gah, mold!|Huh. Mold.
I forgot I had some left-over\nbread. I'd better throw it away.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 먹다 만 빵이 있었다는 걸\n까먹었어.... 버려야겠다.

English (United States)(en-US): What's “mold”? I get the sense\nit's something you don't like.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 곰팡이'가 뭐야? 네가\n이걸 싫어하는 게 느껴져.

English (United States)(en-US): It's what grows in damp or\ndark places, or on spoiled, rotten food.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 곰팡이는 습하거나 어두운 곳, 상하거나\n썩은 음식 등에서 피어나는 생물이야.

English (United States)(en-US): Sorry about that.
I hope it doesn't give you the wrong idea\nabout Earth on your first day here.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 지구에 온 첫날부터\n이런 걸 보게 하다니.

English (United States)(en-US): I'll get rid of it. That'll make\nthe desk much cleaner!
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 얼른 치워야겠다. 그럼\n책상이 훨씬 깨끗해질 거야!

English (United States)(en-US): Damp or dark places...
Spoiled, rotten food?
Oh. Oh....
<nickname>, wait.
Wait. Don't get rid of it.
I'd like to spend time with it.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 나, 얘와 시간을 보내 보고 싶어.

English (United States)(en-US): May I?
But why? Isn't it dirty and gross?
Please, <nickname>.
(If it's just for a few days...)
Alright then.
...... Hello?
...... I saw terrible filth on the Moon.
Is there filth on Earth as well?\nWere you born from it too?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 지구에도 그런 게 있니.\n너도 그곳에서 태어났어?

English (United States)(en-US): Can you grow on the\ncorpses of rotten dreams?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): ... 넌 썩은 꿈의 시체에서도.\n피어날 수 있어?

English (United States)(en-US): Are you not afraid of dirty,\nfoul-smelling things?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 넌 불결하고 냄새 나는\n것들을 두려워하지 않아?

English (United States)(en-US): Are you not afraid of me?
Why?
How?
How very strange.
But thank you.
It's nice.
We're alike, you and me.
Perhaps we can be what\nhumans call friends.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 인간들이 친구라고 부르는\n걸 우리도 할 수 있겠어.

English (United States)(en-US): <nickname>!
I was so absorbed I didn't\neven hear your footsteps.
Even though it usually wakes\nme from my daydreams.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 몽상하던 나를 눈 뜨게\n하는 것인데도 말이야.

English (United States)(en-US): I'm sorry.
Were you looking for me?\nDid you call out my name?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 나를 찾았어? 혹시\n나를 몇 번이나 불렀어?

English (United States)(en-US): That's alright, I just got here.|I was worried something had happened.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 아냐, 나도 방금 왔으니 괜찮아.|무슨 일이 있는 걸까 걱정했어.

English (United States)(en-US): You're sweet. Like a soft, fluffy cloud.
What were you so absorbed in, Dot?
A book!
An act called 'reading'\nhas enchanted me.
Books are magical, they capture\nmy soul and draw me in.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 책은 아주 오래되고 투명한 마법 같아,\n날 붙잡고 그 안으로 속절없이 끌어당기지.

English (United States)(en-US): Their inner workings are\nsomething special.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그 체계는 다른 매체와는 조금 달라.

English (United States)(en-US): Really, some books truly do\nspeak the very language I crave!
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 정말이야, 내가 정말이지 필요로\n하는 표현 방식을 구사해, 어떤 책은!

English (United States)(en-US): From poems that are loudest\nwhen words are left unsaid,
to novels that care for each and every\nintricate layer of the narrative.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 켜켜히 쌓이며 이야기를 만들어 내는\n소설은 내가 특히 좋아하는 종류야.

English (United States)(en-US): It's subtle but sweet.
Like I'm being asked,
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): “내가 하는 말을 있는\n그대로 느낄 수 있어?”

English (United States)(en-US): “Do you feel me word by word?”
Sometimes like a friendly exchange\nthat takes place in complete silence!
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 가끔은 책과 내가 주고받는\n놀이처럼 느껴질 수도 있지!

English (United States)(en-US): And that's what\nhas enchanted me.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그 모든 것들이 날 빠지게 만든 거야.

English (United States)(en-US): (An alien creature\nin love with books.)
(How romantic. Can Dot emphathize with a story?)|(How fascinating! How does Dot read and comprehend?)
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): (낭만적이야. 책에 공감할 수 있으려나?)|(신기해! 글은 어떻게 읽고 이해하는 거지?)

English (United States)(en-US): But then again...
The television, the radio, or the\nworld outside isn't always so.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): TV나 라디오나 내가 직접 본\n세상은 꼭 그렇지만은 않아.

English (United States)(en-US): And neither are you, <nickname>.
When you were out, I had my head\nburied in books. Lots of them.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 외출하거나, 대화하지 않는\n시간에 책을 읽었어. 많이.

English (United States)(en-US): <nickname>, when you talk to me,
walk me through the pages of your mind,
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 납득할 수 있는 설명을 내게 충분히 줘.

English (United States)(en-US): just like these books do.
Or share with me a way to understand you.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그렇지 않다면 그 시선으로\n볼 수 있는 틀을 줘.

English (United States)(en-US): I want to cross the water between us
and sink alongside you.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 내가 같은 편에서 침잠할 수 있게.

English (United States)(en-US): To follow your inner tides,\nthe patterns of their rise and fall.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 네 안의 파도, 그의 하얗게 부서지며\n호흡하는 너만의 숨을 오롯이 느낄 수 있게.

English (United States)(en-US): Or else we'll never know.
Forever strangers,\ndrowning in our solitude.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 서로에게 영원한 이방인으로 남은 채\n잊히다가, 메말라 죽어 버릴 거야.

English (United States)(en-US): Whatever you tell me, I'll always\nbe listening. So let me in.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 아무리 난해할지라도 나는 전부\n듣고 있으니까. 들여보내 줘.

English (United States)(en-US): Don't leave me out there.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 날 그 너머에 내버려 두지 마.

English (United States)(en-US): Blue, blue.\nSound, sound.
Present... present.
What are you doing, Dot?|(Wait and see what Dot is up to.)
I'm musing over the human language.\nCertain words are peculiar, <nickname>.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 인간의 언어를 흥미로워하고 있었어!\n그런데 이 특정 언어들은 이상해, <nickname>.

English (United States)(en-US): They look and sound the same\nbut their insides aren't so.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 똑같은 모양, 똑같은 소리 안에\n똑같지 않은 뜻과 마음이 담겨 있어.

English (United States)(en-US): Sometimes words that look\nthe same have different meanings.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 맞아, 우리 언어에서는 똑같이 생긴\n단어가 다른 의미로 사용될 수 있지.

English (United States)(en-US): Blue, the color of the sea.\nAnd blue, a sense of dull melancholy.
Sound, what echoes in your room.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 동화, 아이들의 신비롭고\n다정한 책장 속 놀이터.

English (United States)(en-US): Sound, a state of firm tranquility.\nClosed eyes and a settled pulse.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 동화, 곁에 있는 무언가를\n닮아가며 비슷해지는 현상.

English (United States)(en-US): Present, the time. And present, a gift.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 푸르른 것들에 붙이는 수식, 파란.\n푸르른 바다에 너울대는 물결, 파란.

English (United States)(en-US): Blue-blue, sound-sound,\npresent-present!
<nickname>, guess what.
Saying these words,
are like rolling identical marbles on your\ntongue and tasting different flavors.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 똑 닮은 구슬을 혀끝에서 굴려 보았을 때\n전혀 다른 맛이 나는 것과 같아.

English (United States)(en-US): Wow, that's a great way to put it.|That's what we call a polysemy.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 우와, 멋진 표현인데?|그걸 우린 다의어라고 해.

English (United States)(en-US): Let's say each meaning is a flavor,\nand a word the marble that encases it.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 맞아, '의미와 뜻'이 하나의 맛이고, 단어는\n그것을 가둬 둔 구슬이라 생각해 보자.

English (United States)(en-US): There are numerous intangible\n'flavors' in the world, and within us.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 세상에는, 그리고 마음 안에는\n수많은 비정형의 '맛'들이 존재해.

English (United States)(en-US): To deliver them we made marbles, or words,\nbut sometimes there weren't enough.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그걸 전달하고자 단어라는 구슬을 만들었는\n데, 때로는 그 개수가 부족할 때도 있었지.

English (United States)(en-US): So we had to add a few more\nflavors to a single marble!
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그래서 하나의 구슬 안에 몇 가지\n맛들을 더 넣어야 했던 거야!

English (United States)(en-US): It's quite common\nin the human language.
If a single word is a single box, different\nmeanings can coexist in that 'box'.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 하나의 단어가 하나의 틀이라면, 그 '틀' 안\n엔 여러 의미가 공존하며 살아 있을 수 있지.

English (United States)(en-US): “Pardon, I would like to use the same box,”\none meaning might say to another.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): “실례지만 당신과 같은 틀을 좀 사용하겠습\n니다”, 한 의미가 다른 의미에게 말을 걸어.

English (United States)(en-US): “Do you find your assigned\nword to your liking?”
—such conversations might\ntake place in a respectful manner.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그들은 이런 식으로 정중하게 이야기를\n나누며 지낼 수도 있지 않을까.

English (United States)(en-US): Won't humans get confused\nwhen they use these words?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 인간들이 단어를 주고받을 때... 서로 어떤\n의미를 의도한 것인지 헷갈리지는 않을까?

English (United States)(en-US): Of course. But that's the\ncharm of human language.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 당연히 헷갈리지. 하지만 그게 인간\n언어의 매력이라고 볼 수 있다고 생각해.

English (United States)(en-US): It's open to confusion.
Oh!
I want to try something. Can you make\nme a sentence with these sets of words?
Blue, blue, sound, sound,\nand present, present.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 꿈, 꿈, 동화, 동화, 파란, 파란.\n이 단어들로 하나의 문장을 만들어 줄래?

English (United States)(en-US): A sentence that welcomes\nconfusion with open arms,
and makes the human\nlanguage as charming as can be!
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 인간 언어의 매력을 최대로\n증폭한 문장을 말이야!

English (United States)(en-US): First, blue and blue.
Next, sound and sound.
And finally, present and present.
Now its twice as much fun!
<nickname>, language excites me...\nbut confuses me very, very, very much.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): <nickname>, 언어라는 건 날 들뜨게 하는 동시에...\n아주, 아주, 아주 어렵고 혼란하게 해.

English (United States)(en-US): I'll return to my corner now. I'd like\nto try out more of these marbles.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 이제 다시 돌아갈게, 나의 머릿속으로.\n더 많은 구슬들을 발음해 보고 싶어.

English (United States)(en-US): What is that under the bed?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 침대 아래 무언가 있는 것 같아!

English (United States)(en-US): Sorry?
I was just writing in my diary, and now\nI'd like to try an interesting game with you.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 일기를 쓰다가, 낮에 봤던 흥미로운\n놀이를 너와 해 보고 싶어졌어.

English (United States)(en-US): Making up a complete\nstory with just six words.
Don't you need to focus on your diary?|I was just in the mood for a chat.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 일기 쓰기에 집중하지 않아도 돼?|때마침 나도 수다 상대가 필요했어.

English (United States)(en-US): I thought my mind could use\na break from all that writing.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 작문하던 나의 지성에게 숨 쉴\n공간을 주는 것도 좋을 듯했지!

English (United States)(en-US): They say that a celebrated\nnovelist wrote this one:
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그래서 말이야, 어떤 저명한\n작가는 이렇게 썼다고 해.

English (United States)(en-US): "For sale: baby shoes. Never worn."
I can almost hear the baby's final\nbreath, see the mother's numb grief,
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 아기의 마지막 숨소리가 들리고, \n어머니의 텅 빈 슬픔이 내려앉아.

English (United States)(en-US): feel the suffocating silence\necho in the empty nursery...
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 끔찍하지. 방에 메아리치는 비탄과\n죽음의 손아귀, 그리고 정적...

English (United States)(en-US): All this in only six words.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 이 모든 걸 고작 여섯\n단어 안에 내포하다니.

English (United States)(en-US): The weight of what's left unsaid. How it\nseizes the heart and refuses to let go.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 단어 간 여백의 무게가 내 마음을\n꼭 쥔 채 묵직하게 짓누르고 있어.

English (United States)(en-US): Pure genius!
So... I made up a six-word story too!
Then I spent the rest of the day imagining\n87 ways my story could unfold.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그리고 하루종일 내 이야기를 이어나갈\n수 있는 87가지의 갈래를 생각해봤어.

English (United States)(en-US): Here's my 16th idea:
"What is that under the bed? It looks scary."\nsaid <nickname>. It was a dark, dark night.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): “침대 아래 무언가 있는 것 같아.”\n라고 네가 중얼거렸어. 깜깜한 밤이었지.

English (United States)(en-US): "Don't be scared. I won't hurt you."\nwhispered an echoing voice.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): “무서워하지 마. 난 널 해치지 않아.”\n조그마한 목소리가 속삭였지.

English (United States)(en-US): "It's only... me! Boo!" said I, popping\nout from under the bed! Hehe.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): “왜냐하면... 나인 걸! 놀랐지!”\n하고 내가 침대 밑에서 튀어나와!

English (United States)(en-US): Do you like it? I wrote it especially for you.
Of course I do.
<nickname>, <nickname>.\nI'm curious.
How would you continue my six-word story?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 너라면 내 이야기를 어떻게 이어나갈 거야?

English (United States)(en-US): That is, what <i>is<\i> that under the bed?
“There is something under the bed.”
Oh! Oh! There you have it!\It's a great idea!
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 오! 오와! 정말 놀라워!\n정말 멋진 아이디어야!

English (United States)(en-US): Alright. Now that I've given my\nmind its well-deserved rest,
I will now go back to my diary.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 난 이만 다시 일기를 쓰러 가 볼게.

English (United States)(en-US): And my first ever entry!
